claim: If tiger sharks stop swimming, nothing in particular happens to them.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor, suggesting they can survive brief periods without swimming.
These resting periods are rare and typically occur in areas with strong currents that passively move water over their gills.
Tiger sharks in captivity have survived in tanks with artificial water flow, showing they don't always need to swim actively.
Captive environments are artificial and don't reflect natural conditions where passive oxygenation is unreliable.

supporting.text: If tiger sharks stop swimming, they would suffocate due to lack of oxygen from water flow over their gills.

attacks.text: If tiger sharks stop swimming, they would suffocate due to lack of oxygen from water flow over their gills.
Some shark species can actively pump water over their gills while stationary, but tiger sharks are obligate ram ventilators.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor in rare cases, suggesting limited ability to survive without swimming.
Even if tiger sharks could survive briefly without swimming, prolonged immobility would still lead to oxygen deprivation.
The claim ignores the fundamental biological dependence of tiger sharks on ram ventilation for respiration.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks lack the physiological adaptations to pump water over their gills while stationary, unlike some other shark species.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks lack the physiological adaptations to pump water over their gills while stationary, unlike some other shark species.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor, suggesting they can survive brief periods without swimming.
These observations are rare and may represent stressed or dying individuals rather than normal behavior.
Tiger sharks can utilize ram ventilation at very low speeds, reducing their need for constant swimming.
This low-speed ventilation still requires some forward movement and wouldn't support complete stillness.

supporting.text: Scientific studies on tiger shark physiology confirm their dependence on constant movement for respiration.

attacks.text: Scientific studies on tiger shark physiology confirm their dependence on constant movement for respiration.
Some shark species exhibit buccal pumping, allowing them to respire without continuous movement.
Tiger sharks are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they cannot switch to buccal pumping like some other species.
Sharks in captivity have been observed resting motionless on the sea floor without apparent respiratory distress.
Captive environments often use artificial water flow to simulate ram ventilation, invalidating observations of 'resting' behavior.
